lines.text: Wait! There's something interesting in that woman's smile. I might learn to like her. Hang her in my bathroom.
Absolutely not! I'm a businessman. I love money, I love power, I love capitalism. I do not now and never will love children.
I guess they're dead. I guess I've known that deep down for a long time.
I'm not giving up. Don't you give up.
I didn't want to be just another orphan, Mr. Warbucks. I wanted to believe I was special.
You *are* special! *Never* stop believing that!
May I take your sweater, miss?
Will I get it back?

[singing]
Some women are drippin' with diamonds / Some women are drippin' with pearls / Lucky me, lucky me, look at what I'm drippin' with / Little girls!
Where's Annie?
She had to go bathroom.

[Imitating Molly]
She had to go, bathroom.
But they wasn't her real parents, mister, they was bad people!
Leapin' lizards!
I never thought I'd get used to a girl.
Girls are easier to get used to than boys. Look how used to Miss Farrell you are. She does all the work around here, and you don't even know her first name.
I do, it's Grace.
She thinks you're the greatest thing since sliced bread.

[surprised]
I beg your pardon?
I know it's none of my business, but you never notice anything!
You love money and power and capitalism? You know they're never going to love you back...

What are you just standing around here for? You're supposed to clean the bathroom and the kitchen before lunch, my little pig droppings, and if you skip the corners, there will be no lunch. And we're not having hot mush today...
Yay!
We're having *cold* mush!
You can have any orphan in the whole orphanage... except Annie.
Well, why?
Because she's got it comin' to her; and I *don't* mean 'a week in the lap of luxury'!
The swimming pool is down the stairs.
Inside the house? Oh. boy.
The tennis court is in the rear.
I never even picked up a racket.
What? Have an instructor here at noon. And get that Don Budge fellow if he's available.
I think I'm gonna like It here.
Miss Hannigan, I presume?
Yes?
I wanna talk to you about Annie.
You wanna return her and forget her? Or trade up?
I wanna adopt her.
Would you excuse me for a moment? Aaarggghh!
We got Annie!
We got Annie!
We got Annie!
Oh sir. We are just so thrilled to have found Annie. We don't need any money.
I'll take it back.
Of course, we are poor people. It would help us a lot. We could buy her milk, a warm blanket.
Put it in your pocket, Mrs. Mudge.
Your teeth are crooked.
I'll get them fixed.
I like them crooked.

[whispering]
I'll leave 'em.
This is Lily St. Regis.
Named from the hotel.
Room service!
You'll sit out this century in some deep, dark penitentiary.
Jail?
Sign.
I geuss this means I'll never know the feeling of running fingers through your hair.
You'll rot in jail. In Sing-Sing.
I guess this means no Bonus Iree.
Will you sign?
Buddha says "A child without courage is like a night without stars!"
We love you, Miss Hannigan.
Shut up!
What about this child?
Annie?... Oh, you don't want Annie.
Why not?
Because... Because she's a drunk!
Little girls, little girls, everywhere I turn I can see them.
Miss Hannigan. I am the private secretary to Oliver Warbucks.
The Oliver Warbucks? Oliver Warbucks, the millionaire?
Oh no. Oliver Warbucks, the billionaire.
Mary, mother of God.
I don't need sunshine now to turn my skies to blue. I Don't Need anything but you.
What did you say your name was?
Grace Farrell
Ah, Grace, aptly name.
You spend your evenings in the shanties.
You had me followed.
Imbibing quarts of bathtub gin.
Bronchitism.
And here you're dancing in your scanties,
Great gams.
With some old geezer called Little Caeser,
He's an uncle.
You lock the orphans in the closet.
They love it!
You hock their Christmas souvenirs.
Drink?
You steal the funds you should deposit.
It's fresh.
You make them grovel while you buy laveleers.

[to Annie]
Blow it out your old wa-zoo!
Why any kid would want to be an orphan is beyond me.
I bet you Miss Sticky Fingers here can loan you a lousy five bucks.
I beg your pardon, I'm sure, but I don't stoop to what you're incineratin'.
Give me back my goods, toots.
[Lily hands Miss Hannigan the jewelry that she had been holding. Miss Hannigan clears her throat and stares at Lily's chest. Lily then pulls the rest of the jewelry out of her dress]
All right, who's next? Anybody else? Then get lost!
Annie, how would you like to spend a week with Mr. Warbucks at his house?
Oh boy! I would love to. I would really, really love to.
Leaping lizards!
"Leaping lizards!"
Pepper lies a lot. She probably hasn't been to a movie, either. Actually, I think it's better when you don't know what you're missing.
00 show. Let's all go to the movies.
Everyone - Republicans too, Oliver - sing!

[as she looks at the diamond pin Daddy Warbucks is wearing]
My God, is that thing real?
Don't be so mean, you mean old meanie.
Come my dear.
Let's you and me make, why shouldn't we make hey.
I've got an appointment at one.
This way. You every been to Bonus Iree?
Where?
I hunger for the Ar-gen-tine
Argen-teena.
Let's you and me fill up our diaries!
What? Stop!
Buy me a ruby.
No!
Why shouldn't you be mine?

[sings]
It's the hard knock life for us.

[sings]
It's the hard knock life for us / 'Steada treated... we get tricked! / 'Steada kisses... we get kicked! / It's the hard knock life!

[while tearing up the check]
Mr. Warbucks will eat your livers!
I'll kill ya, ya little brat. I'll kill ya!

[to herself]
He's really gonna kill her!
[while chasing Rooster and Annie]
Rooster! Rooster stop! Rooster, she's a baby!
They say it can land on a dime... whatever that may be.
The sun'll come out tomorrow, so you gotta hang on 'til tomorrow. Come what may. Tomorrow, tomorrow, I love ya, Tomorrow. You're only a day away.
I want to feed them and house them and pay them. Not much, but enough to send home to their parents. So they can hold their heads up again and be proud to be Americans.
That's a swell idea.
It isn't a swell idea, Annie. It's mistaken foolishness.
Who would want to kill Mr. Warbucks?
The Bolsheviks, dear. He's living proof that the American system really works and the Bolsheviks don't want anyone to know about that.
The Bolsheviks? Leapin' lizards!
What do we say, Annie?
I love you Miss Hannigan.
[Jumps from the bed on to her foot]
I love you, Daddy Warbucks.
Easy Street. Easy Street. Annie is the key.
Yessiree.
Yessiree.
Yessiree.
It's time for a tumble with the bundle.
You've given me so much already, Mr. Warbucks.
I got the papers signed today, it's official.
What is?
[Warbucks pulls out the locket]
It's so pretty, but...
Let me put it on you.
No. It's a really swell locket, Mr. Warbucks, but if it's all the same to you, I'll keep my old one.
'To Annie, with love, from... Daddy Warbucks.

Mr. Warbucks, when my folks left me at the orphanage ten years ago, they left a note saying they'd come back to get me as soon as they could, and they kept the other half of this old locket so I'd know them when they came. I'm going to find them someday, Mr. Warbucks. I'm going to have a regular mother and father, like a regular kid. I am! I don't mean to hurt your feelings. You've been nicer to me than anybody in the whole wide world, but I've been dreaming of my folks for as long as I can remember, and I've just got to find them.
[last lines]

[sings]
Tomorrow, tomorrow, I love ya, Tomorrow... You're only a day away!
We love you, Ms. Hannigan
Sure.
Rooster, you reprobate!
[first lines]

[having a nightmare]
Annie! Annie! Annie! Annie!
Everything is going to be alright.
[repeated line]
Oh, my goodness! Oh, my goodness!
[repeated line]
Leapin' lizards!
